description: From Middle English agu, ague, borrowed from Middle French (fievre) aguë, “acute (fever)” (Modern French fièvre aiguë), from Late Latin (febris) acuta (“acute fever”), from Latin acūtus (“sharp, acute”) + febris (“fever”).

entries.meaning: (pathology) An intermittent fever, attended by alternate cold and hot fits.
examples: 'Ague and lake fever had attacked our new settlement. The men in the shanty were all down with it, and my husband was confined to his bed on each alternate day, unable to raise hand or foot, and raving in the delirium of the fever.'

entries.meaning: The cold fit or rigor of the intermittent fever
A chill, or state of shaking, as with cold.
examples: I 'scap'd with one cold fit of an ague
Where I'm from, people have learned that mosquitoes carry ague.

verbs.description: ague (third-person singular simple present agues, present participle aguing, simple past and past participle agued)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To strike with an ague, or with a cold fit.
